Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Behavioural Recovery in Varicose Vein Treatments

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised using a minimization algorithm

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adults with primary symptomatic varicose veins (CEAP grade C2 or above) and specific vein involvement.

Intervention.evidence: comparing ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy (UGFS), endovenous laser ablation (EVLA), and surgery for primary varicose veins.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess behavioural recovery from the patient's perspective

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was behavioural recovery, assessed using the 15-item BRAVVO questionnaire at 6 weeks post-treatment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 798 participants were randomised: 265 to UGFS, 267 to EVLA, and 266 to surgery.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of these, 655 completed the BRAVVO questionnaire.

Result_Outcome.evidence: UGFS was superior to EVLA for full-time work (HR 1.43, 95% CI 1.11 to 1.85), childcare (HR 1.45, 95% CI 1.04 to 2.02), and walking (short: HR 1.48, 95% CI 1.19 to 1.84; long: HR 1.32, 95% CI 1.05 to 1.66).

Funding.evidence: The trial was funded by the National Institute for Health Research.
